displayed_text: Patient: Yeah ‘cause the ones you gave me you prescribed they was they was they jumped out of my skin. Doctor: What is his uh… Healthcare Professional: Those and morphine sixty Doctor: No he gets a breakthrough also right? Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Patient: I shoulda brought the… I shoulda brought the pill bottle with me. Doctor: Yeah, okay. So morphine is sixty huh? Can I stick with the same doses? We don’t need to change anything do we of the pain medicine? Patient: Not right now. Doctor: Okay. So the morning and evening dose you’re taking of the morphine? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. (pause7sec) Patient: Yes. Doctor: How’s your mom doing?

Patient: Okay. Is that the – Doctor: Xtandi. Patient: Xtandi. Okay. That was a shot once a month or? Doctor: That was the pills you were taking. Patient: Oh, I did take them. Yeah. Okay. Doctor: So that would say if we did that just as a course of action and the likelihood it’s gonna help you is pretty low. Patient: Oh. Doctor: And so, this study is looking at a new therapy –uh, the hottest new drugs that are out there, and when we’ve given them to men with prostate cancer, we haven’t seen a whole lot. (Pause) Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Um. And the two drugs together, uh, may be, uh, cause responses. Uh, but we don’t know. And that’s why we’re doing a research study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we’re giving folks who’ve got bad disease this because the worry is these drugs may have a lot of side effects. Most of the time, they’re tolerated well, but what they do is they turn on your immune system, hope that your immune system is going to attack your cancer, but I also could turn on your immune system with these medicines and it attacks you. Okay? So you can get a pneumonia that’s from your immune system. You can get hepatitis because it’s attacking your liver. You could get colitis ‘cuz it’s attacking your colon. Uh, it usually picks one organ, not not all of ‘em, but, you know, you can get into trouble because your immune system – while it’s tryin’ to fight your cancer, it’s tryin’ to fight you. Uh. And when we Patient: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the –

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know, if down the road if there are kidney problems. At least what they’ve reported so far they don’t - they don’t see it. Patient: I see. Doctor: So I would say the procedure, I normally do it on the trials, but I had this experience with the guys in Germany. What they do is they bring you there and they scan you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: With the imaging part. They see how active is your cancer. How much of the stuff is there on PSMA. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If there’s a lot there, so things look really dark, it looks like it’s taken up like crazy, then you’re a good candidate for that treatment. If it’s so-so, I don’t know what their line is, but they kind of look at it, and if it doesn’t look like the cancer is really taken off, I don’t think you’re a candidate. I would say that most people are in the first group that the cancer makes a lot of this uh so uh one of the things we’re doing here is uh looking at the scan part. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we’ve been looking at the imaging part to see how useful this is as an imaging agent but it’s also useful because if we do it here, and you’re very positive, it might suggest yes we should pursue this. Patient: Okay. Is it something than can tell you how extensive the cancer? Doctor: Yes. So the second part of that, it’s a good question. Just to, and because it’s very sensitive, it’s possible you do the scan, and they, say, oh, B__, your set of these, so many things you see here, there’s a lot more. Because they can see uh, what we’re limited by right now is as I told you these lymph nodes are enlarged. That’s pretty much all the radiologist can say right now. So if you have a normal lymph node it could be totally full of cancer. They won’t call it. They only call the ones that are bigger than normal.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: In a perfect world, I should be able to print that so that you don’t have to go through that. Patient: That’s okay. Doctor: I can place it for - over the - Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So uh we’ll place an order. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Do you want to do it in two months or three months? Do you have any preference? Patient: Well when am I going to see you again? Doctor: January would be reasonable. How about three months from now? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Do it about a week or two before? If I see you in mid-January?

Patient: What would you recommend? Doctor: Okay so my recommendation is mainly based on trying our best not to take away options from you, okay. And the way I see it if we go to Lynparza right now, this Xtandi plus BET1 inhibitor goes away as an option because you have to be on the Xtandi currently before when they can consider you for the study. So I’m leaning towards if you qualify for the study, if everything goes right then you should go with the Xtandi plus BET inhibitor the study based option first and if that doesn’t work or if it doesn’t if you’re not eligible for whatever reason, then we go to the Lynparza. I mean that is available to us as a fall back at any point. Family Member: Okay. Patient: So you’d say try the uh uh BET thing and uh if that doesn’t work go to the Lynparza which is the PARP inhibitor and continue with the Xtandi? Family Member: With, with the BET. Doctor: The Lynparza we’ll see, most likely I will stop the Xtandi at that point. Patient: Okay do you think… Doctor: Because we’ll really have exhausted that Xtandi is not working definitely before we decide to switch to Lynparza at that point. Patient: How soon will you know? I mean the… Family Member: With the BET. Doctor: With the BET? Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: Oh yeah. Doctor: The garage I’m not evening tackling. Family Member: The basement. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah same thing. (Laughs) Family Member: Good luck. Doctor: Good luck is right. Patient: So I all need to do now is go back to the lab and do… Doctor: No, no you’re probably gonna stay here and S__ will take you over because those are special tubes that she has to send out and all that. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: And would it be possible for me to have copies of that stuff? Doctor: Yeah I thought you might I know you usually want some. This is the bone scan. Patient: And my PSA wasn’t on the sheet. Do you guys have a number on that?

Family Member: Maybe put that down so you can focus some again on the radium study. Doctor: So I, I was going to talk to you about a radioactive thing we have that’s very specifically targeted the prostate cancer cells. Uh, I keep telling folks about it, and then it keeps taking too long, and we haven’t opened the trial yet. I thought we were going to open it in August. It’s now December. Family Member: What’s the name of it? Patient: Radium. Doctor: Well, no, the radium’s a different thing. So the radium, uh, this is called, this is just, it’s P-S-M-A, targeted, uh. Family Member: But it hasn’t gotten here yet? They looking at it in kind of-? Doctor: So, they’ve, they’ve tested it in Europe in a, in a weird way. So in Europe, the doctors there are allowed to, if they think something could work, they’re allowed to just give it to people. They don’t need FDA kind of approval. Doctor: They don’t need, uh, even data showing that it proves survival. It’s sort of, if, if the doctor feels it could be beneficial, they’re allowed to use it. So they’re not allowed to sell it. They not allowed to make money. So what they’ve been doing is based on using the same material to image prostate cancer. So we give this material with a little bit of radiation on it and it looks really good. We could see spots that we maybe didn’t see before. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: The idea was, well, if we can swap out the little bit of radiation and put a lot of radiation, maybe we could treat cancer. So they’ve been treating people kind of on an individual basis. Somebody calls up, shows up, you give it to them. They haven’t said, let’s take a hundred guys with this, you know, kind of like a trial. So they’ve been reporting look how good Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So in the U.S., we kind of have to go down more organized, you know, step-wise fashion. Family Member: Um hum.

Patient: No, there you go. Doctor: Oh, thank you. Patient: You’re welcome. Doctor: That is very sweet. Family Member: Yeah, it is. Doctor: Thank you, that’s special, though; thank you. Okay, so the other big thing is that this chemo will cause hair loss. You probably will notice; most people notice it after about a couple of courses. But you know it’s possible Patient: What’s the Doctor: -that it may happen right after the first – Patient: What’s the, yeah, how about enlightening me on how much time are we talking about before - Doctor: So, so my plan right now is to give you about two or three courses and do a repeat scan. Patient: That’s uh - Doctor: So one time every three weeks is called one cycle. So today if you get it, that’s your first cycle of treatment. Next treatment will be due in three weeks from today. Patient: Oh it’s every three weeks.

Family Member: But the study itself is for two years. Doctor: Yes, yes. Yes, yes. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: All right. So let me, um yeah, so this is the so this is the part that's part of the research that's going to be free of charge. So right now what we'll do is the blood for this is the specific gene that we're looking for. And then if you join the study, and you have the right genotype, we'll get all of these and then these other things are not part of their like part of standard treatment. So those don't get paid for by the study they get paid for by your insurance company as normal. Patient: By insurance. Doctor: So if you are okay with this, I will get your signature there and then. You have to put the time. Time is 450 Family Member: So he’ll go downstairs and get his blood drawn. Doctor: Yes. All right. So let me make a copy of this though for you for your records. Family Member: We’re very thankful for meeting you. And how thorough you are. And how comfortable, you make you know, it makes me feel comfortable. Doctor: Thank you. Thank you. I always tell me I'm not happy that we met under the circumstances- Patient: Yes. Doctor: - but try make the best of it.

Family Member: Oh, yeah, that’d be great. Patient: So, that’ll be two then. We’ll have two going on at the same time. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you’ll keep your Xtandi, Family Member: Xtandi, okay. Doctor: and then we’ll throw on a second medication. Patient: What are the names of the other two drugs? Doctor: No names. All letters and numbers. Family Member: Good. Doctor: Poof! You just turn into a guinea pig again. You were there before, but yeah. I think that’s the hard part. It’s umm, you know, they don’t give names unless it’s moving along the path of development. Umm. And then uh, it’s sorta like you don’t name your pet…you don’t think you’re gonna keep it. I don’t know. Patient: Ahhh.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then to start hormone therapy and to have a consult with radiation and I’m… it’s okay to have a consult with them. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: I wouldn’t necessarily start the radiation until you get better control. Patient: Right. Doctor: Which will hopefully you’ve made some progress Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: and will continue to. I know G___ asked you a lot about that. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: He wrote three pads and… So do you want to see Dr. F__? Family Member: If it’s okay with you, I mean…

Healthcare Professional: Yep, she just has to sign these first. So… Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: They won't take them without her signature. Doctor: I’m just a - I’m just wondering, how long did we wait? We waited two weeks now? Healthcare Professional: It was two weeks from-- Doctor: Two weeks from his last uh, when he was last due? Healthcare Professional: Yeah Doctor: Okay. So then I- for now I'm going to stay with the same dose. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I think the next step before this tearing and everything, and we are getting up there in number of cycles you've gotten, Patient: Correct. Doctor: we may need to consider cutting back on the dose or--

Patient: The doctors you know. Doctor: Oh doctors, okay. Payments. Because then I was gonna say get that done before we start this whole process. Doctor: Okay so let me let them know okay and then you can leave but we’ll schedule the appointment with me and all that afterwards Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah.and probably Dr. C____ and I will see you same day like we did today. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay? I love that color on you today. Family Member: You know so many people tell me that. Doctor: It looks really nice on you. Family Member: It’s about five years old. (Laughs) Doctor: Oh my gosh, it’s so pretty. Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Is what the trick is? Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Uh, anyway, I’ll, I’ll- Patient: Yeah. If you get a chance. Doctor: Will think about that. Okay. Patient: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. So I will try to get a hold of you Friday. Patient: Uh-Uh. Okay. All right. Sounds good. Doctor: I’ll let them know we’re done so they can- Patient: All right. Doctor: I don’t know where the other camera is. Patient: There’s one there, and one there. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so we’d have to check with your insurance. Do they cover clinical trials, if you’re interested? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, if they are. Then in the forms that we give them and give you, it tells them, huh, what they’re paying for, and it tells you what we’re going to pay for. So definitely the dummy vitamin C or the real vitamin C we pay for because that’s experimental. Your insurance company may have to pay for the time in the chair to get the medicine. Okay? Huh, if you have to pay five dollars every time you come into this building, huh, this study could cost you more money because you’re here more often. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, but if you don’t have a copay for visits, then that’s, you know. So there are some hidden costs. You know? If you’re coming in more often and you have to pay for parking and, you know, those sorts of things, huh, we do have the ability for some of our studies to pay for your parking. We do. Or even if you need a ride here, there’s a group of, do you live in the city? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. We definitely have a program to help city residents if they have trouble getting in that often. Huh, huh, you know, the chemotherapy is going to cause hair loss. Huh, seventy-five percent of the time you lose your hair, it grows back. Huh, you might get excess tearing because it can block the tear ducts. So a little bit. The other reason why we might want to wait a little bit is just to see how much your palsy is going to get better. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, huh, it drops blood counts. So right now your white count’s good. Your platelets are good. Huh, but we may need to give you a blood transfusion if we make you more anemic. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, huh, we can drop your blood count, white count, and so you might get a higher risk of infection. Huh, usually we know about that. We tell you to be careful. Sometimes we give you antibiotics. And if it happens every time, sometimes we’re going to give you a medicine that’s going to bring up your white count so it doesn’t drop. Patient: Okay.
